vision_science_figure_explanation_2.response: Our sun will start shrinking after it has been through its red giant phase. This phase occurs towards the end of its life cycle, which is billions of years from now. During this phase, the sun's core will continue to produce energy, but the outward pressure from the expanding hydrogen shell will cause the outer layers of the sun to balloon outward, making the sun appear larger. The core will slowly contract, while the surface expands outward, until it reaches its maximum size as a red giant. After that, the core will eventually cool down, the energy production will slow down, and the sun will transition into a white dwarf. The process of the sun going through its life cycle is depicted in the provided image. The sun's hydrogen fuel will be completely consumed, and it will become a small, cool, and dim white dwarf, leaving behind a small amount of heavy elements. This is the end of the sun's life cycle and the beginning of a new star, if conditions are favorable for the formation of new stars.

This contrast, combined with the ship's size and its position above the ocean, creates an illusion of it floating above the water. Additionally, the presence of a large body of water and the open sky above provides a sense of depth, further contributing to the illusion.

The image, although seemingly improbable, is a striking example of how atmospheric conditions, contrast, and perspective can lead to optical illusions that alter our perception of reality.
